bibl.title: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 19, 1902

div1.p: Mabel Lazear thanks Sweitzer for corsets she had sent. She provides news of her children, and says her pension bill has passed the House and the Senate.

div1.head: Letter from Mabel H. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, March 19, 1902
div1.p:
I have been
thiking to thank you for the
welcome letter and my beauti-
ful corsets- They fit so well
and are so comfortable. Even
mother has come to the conclusion
that, corset are one thing you
can't get in California- Please
when you write let me know
how much I owe you- If I
had an idea I should put
the check in this letter-
I am so glad to have the
direction for the sweat as it
is for the Doctor who has
been so kind to the children
I am so glad Peggy is to have
another sweater- The lost
one is exactly the right size
and as she has worn the
other two every day they
are a little small-

If Houston should be so
fortunate as to have an
other one I think it would
be well to have it a great
deal larger than the last
one, he grows so fast-
You can almost see him
growing- He and Peggy both
keep me busy they want stories
all the time- She can just
say tory so cute -- and if you
don't tell them loud enough
Houston always say, “Talk harder”
for the last month I have
taken about all the care
of them- The nurse I have
had for some time was not
well so that she has just
come in at times to relieve
me- If I only had a little
more strength I would
not think of being bother
with a nurse- It means
one more to look out for.
The Baby is so cute when you
go in her room at night
and ask her what is the
matter she always says
“Cryin! bottie!-

I suppose you have heard
the Bill for the pension
has passed the House &
Senate- I had such a de-
lightful note from Dr Gilman
congratulating me and sending
all the letters he had re-
ceive about it, thinking I
would like to keep them
for the children- He also
enclosed a clipping in which
it said that his remarks
about Jess were more en-
thusiasticly received than
about any one else of
whom he spoke.

I should indeed think
the trip to Mrs McCallan
would be delightful and
just what you needed
Her house must seem al-
most like home you have
known her so long.

Pardon the lead pencil
but as I am writing this
in bed having retired at
my usual hour 7.30 I
found a pen to hard to
manage- What a dread-
ful thing the fire was at
Bryn Mawr!-

Give my last love to Aunt
Kate.- A great deal for yourself
from Mabel and the Babies
and many thanks for filling
a long and much needed
want in the corsets
